column5: See you in the New Year at @cshirky@geekdom.social
I‚Äôve been part of a lot of things that have died ‚Äî usenet, MUDs, so many mailing lists ‚Äî but this is the only one I‚Äôve been on that was murdered while it was healthy.

He never had a plan for making Twitter better for anyone but people like him and people who like him. 

But he would still prefer to destroy the version of Twitter that didn‚Äôt worship people like him than let it continue to be its old, messy, cosmopolitan self.
But poetic justice is the only kind we‚Äôre going to get, because as he destroys this place so many of us have loved, he'll still have won in the end.

There is some poetic justice watching @elonmusk fuck up on here.

He‚Äôs turned Tesla‚Äôs brand from ‚Äòcool *and* sustainable‚Äô to ‚Äòself-driving MAGA hat‚Äô and shown investors he‚Äôs reckless enough to incinerate billions of their dollars to pwn a chat client where his feelings got hurt.

Musk isn‚Äôt inviting racists and Nazis back on Twitter because of any desire to 'match the law'. 

He‚Äôs doing those things because he approves of racists and Nazis, and sexists and transphobes.

Because @elonmusk is the owner of a privately-held platform, he can craft the speech rules he wants. 

And because he is a petulant narcissist, what he wants is a platform safe for him and other awful white guys, like the whole internet used to be.

Musk was always ambivalent about owning Twitter ‚Äî he threatened acquisition, then tried to bullshit his way out of it, only to run into a court system that wasn‚Äôt impressed with his whining. So now he owns it.

Now that a few places are slightly less deferential to white men, and slightly less hostile to everyone else, millions of those men are losing their minds. When you‚Äôre used to privilege, equality feels like oppression. 

Musk, uniquely, was rich enough to do something about it

And @elonmusk has extreme ‚Äòfree speech for elites‚Äô pathology. He was 23 when Mandela was elected; he grew up in a country where non-white voices were legally silenced. And he has years of experience of his weird stans taking a bullet for his dumbest ideas

https://t.co/2Y9j2ha9Dz

White men have so much cultural power that for us, the First Amendment *feels* like it should let us say anything to anyone we want to.

Everyone else knows what it's like to have their voices matter less, and knows how much speech is silenced in spaces where abuse is allowed.

The belief that the First Amendment ensures freedom to harangue others in private spaces is mainly held by white men. 

We‚Äôre so accustomed to deference, in all arenas of American society, it‚Äôs easy to believe that *not* deferring to us should be illegal, maybe unconstitutional.

The Twitter of 2021 was not in violation of ‚Äòwhat the law allows‚Äô. Nor was the Twitter of 2016, nor the Twitter of 2009. 

That‚Äôs why no one who‚Äôs ever whined ‚ÄúBut muh free speech tho!‚Äù points to specific laws the service violated. Because there are none.

The First Amendment means a church, a bar, a board room, and a social network can have different norms. 

The government can‚Äôt /ban/ most speech in those spaces, but it‚Äôs the owners who decide whether using the N-word or insulting trans people is allowed or forbidden.

A platform that did not "match the law" would, by definition, be doing something illegal, and someone could sue. 

No one does, because private actors setting their own norms *is not a violation of free speech*. 

It‚Äôs how free speech works.

If your publication is pro-Putin, you do not have to publish op-eds against the war in Ukraine. If your religion venerates Jesus, you do not have to let Satanists preach. If your association approves of Likud, you do not have to let BDS supporters join.

In the U.S, the First Amendment is a negative liberty ‚Äî freedom from interference. It gets the government out of policing most speech. 

It appears alongside freedoms of the press, religion, and association, and lets those groups invent their own rules.

Old Twitter is being destroyed, and its epitaph is this bullshit rationale from @elonmusk. 

‚ÄúThat which matches the law‚Äù isn‚Äôt a thing ‚Äî the 1st Amendment *does not specify* an ideal environment for speech. It‚Äôs designed to let different groups adopt different norms. üßµ

@quinnnorton For a surprising number of young people (where it's me being surprised), I think their sexual orientation is 'Whatever', and trying to identify which categories are really real or stably unchanging over time is itself a category error.

@quinnnorton So to say pansexuals are 'just' bisexuals implies that the newer term is merely a relabel for a largely unchanging category. I used to believe that, but I stopped, because I think the kids I see today are just much less identitarian about the issue.

@quinnnorton But after watching my kids navigate this, I've come to believe that many of the labels I grew up with were themselves created by that same oppression. 

The growth of LGBTQIA+ designations suggests not completeness but instability.

@quinnnorton Call that the Stefani Germanotta Thesis, it's what I grew up with: Oppression of gays and lesbians was wrong because it was interfering with their right to express some core and largely immutable part of their identity.

@quinnnorton I used to think that, but I don't anymore. 

Having watched my kids go through adolescence and seeing them try on various labels, I've now decided my old beliefs -- "People have stable, deeply coded attractions", roughly -- was wrong.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill I did a bunch of scenario work in the aughts, and learned that when the sponsoring organization characterizes what you're doing as a 'moonshot', it meant they didn't understand their own circumstances, *and* they didn't understand how we actually got to the moon.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill Yeah, and the disappointment comes from learning how much circumstances matter. Both the moonshot and the iPhone had a technological base already worked out - neither rockets nor mobiles were new - so vision and talent were enough. 

Most projects don't have that advantage.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill I still think the iPhone and W95 were highly context dependent. No consumer OS or mobile phone has been as widely and rapidly adopted since those respective launches. 

So I don't think you can just announce in advance that you're going to have an iPhone moment.

@OrigenOfSpices I'm certain you're not as dumb as you pretend to be on Twitter, but I'll explain it like you are: the letter itself is the threat. 

This is how networks of privilege work: this is a public letter, signed by powerful people, designed as a brushback pitch.
@OrigenOfSpices The fact that they were forced to retract is what's wrong with the original letter. They knew that they didn't have all the facts, but included no such caveat.
@sbarolo You will have a hard time getting anyone who understands the situation to take the opposite of that bet

I wish I could say there's an easy solution, but professionals have closed ranks for centuries. The best we can do is assume that the higher the status of the signatories of a letter like this, the likelier it is motivated by concern for privilege instead of justice.

The people who defended Comraroff without knowing the facts will face no consequences, nor will it dissuade others from writing such a letter for the next abuser. The circularity of professional membership prevents such consequences.

You could see this same pattern in the letters of support for Avital Ronell, or Joi Ito, two other cases where famous academics signed a public defense whose assertions they simply had no way of‚Äîand no interest in‚Äîvetting.

These letters, written in the language of "Not the person we know" and hand-wringing over penalties, are shows of collective solidarity by high-status individuals, designed to warn the institution away from trying too hard to discipline members of the profession from outside.

This concern over loss of status is correct. A job is a profession if the practitioners get to decide who gets punished, for what, and how. This privilege is practically constitutive of professional membership, and members of a profession guard it jealously.
The threat they were responding to is that whenever the institution gains the power to pass judgment on any academic, for any reason, it is an erosion of the status of all academics.

It is impossible any of them believed they had all the facts when they organized to defend Comaroff. They signed anyway, because of the threat to faculty privilege represented by Harvard's (very mild) discipline of Comaroff so far‚Äîadministrative leave.

The signatories are professors, socialized into academia's core tenet: it is better to be late than wrong. These people will study one more book or paper if they think it will reduce their risk of being publicly incorrect.

Many of the faculty who publicly supported Comaroff, the Harvard prof accused of sexual harassment, are now saying "they regretted signing the letter without knowing more about the situation."

So what is this 'Auto-copying a user's inbox' attack called? And are there good references about how to think about it, and reverse the danger/damage? Many thanks for any pointers. 7/fin

Anyway, The fix is simple - delete the auto-forward - but distinctly non-obvious. This a risk I haven't seen widely emphasized, while 'Change your passwords' is still the main message, one defeated for a large number of sites by auto-forwarding. 6/
Hijackable is too a word. I refuse to bow to the narrow-minded thugs in the employ of Big Orthography. 5/

Auto-forward disables password resets. Change your Gmail password 10 times, and the attacker still gets all your mail. And any site that is like "Forgot password? No problemo! We'll mail you a new one!" is hijackable for as long as the forwarding is in place. 4/

Auto-forward is three clicks deep in Gmail: 'Settings->See All Settings->Forwarding and POP/IMAP.'  Having those last two acronyms is like labeling a link "Authorized Personnel Only" -- no ordinary user thinks "Oh, POP and IMAP, we go way back." 3/

The phishing email was "I'm from Amazon, and I need to talk with you, please call me." ('Call me' evades the phone's spam detection.) My friend gave up their Gmail login, at which point the attacker set up an auto-mail forward to 'spprt.amz1022@gmail.com' 2/
